results.title: Triumph of the will = Triumph des willens
results.brief_description: Triumph of the will is the official film record of the Sixth Nazi Party Congress (Nationalsozialistische Deutsche Arbeiter-Partei. Reichsparteitag) held at Nuremberg, Germany, September 4 to 10, 1934. Leni Riefenstahl produced and directed the film at the order of Hitler. The purpose of the film was propagandistic, and as propaganda, it is an historical landmark, which may never be equalled. It is also a visually beautiful film - showing the supreme pageantry of the Congress and capturing the enthusiasm of the huge crowds (men, women and children of all ages) who took part. As an example of German filmmaking of the period, it is unequalled. The various parades and ceremonies are shown and many of the leaders of the Party who later became so well known are seen. Hitler is also shown giving some of his speeches, which receive a startling reception. Note: In German. No English subtitles.

results.title: Triumph of the spirit
results.creator_credit: Nova International, Shimon Arama, Arnold Kopelson and Robert Young
results.brief_description: The unimaginable horror of Auschwitz is compelling recreated in this overwhelming and powerful story about fighting for survival. Salamo Arouch (Willem Dafoe) is a Greek boxer who fought in the Olympics and is sent to the Auschwitz death camp. There he must battle every day against the inevitability of death with courage and an undaunted will to live being his only weapons. His struggle is a real “Triumph of the spirit.” Co-starring Edward James Olmos and Robert Loggia.

results.title: Triumph of the nomads
results.creator_credit: Douglas Stanley, Nomad Films International and David Morgan
results.brief_description: Ancient Australia is often seen as a land of stagnation and the early Australians were depicted as one of the most primitive peoples on earth. However, this program examines how the long Aboriginal occupation of Australia witnessed spectacular changes. Generations of Aborigines saw the great rising of the seas which isolated Australia; they saw, and probably influenced, sweeping changes in vegetation and wildlife. The Aborigines created a lifestyle which suited their environment. They were skilled herbalists and master trappers and hunters. Their nomadic wanderings followed a logical pattern, reflecting their forethought and knowledge of the land. Narrated by Geoffrey Blainey.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Douglas Stanley, Nomad Films International and David Morgan

results.title: Tristana [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Selina Cinematografia, Epoca Films, Les Films Corona, Talia Films and Luis Bunuel
results.brief_description: Fernando Rey plays Don Lope, a free thinking, Spanish dandy who’s liberal ideals are tested when he is entrusted with the guardianship of the beautiful and innocent Tristana (Catherine Deneuve). Soon enough, fatherly affection develops into full blown lust and obsession, as Don Lope coerces Tristana into becoming his lover, all the while maintaining she is free to see other men. However, Don Lope’s principals begin to fall apart when Tristana meets and falls in love with a handsome young artist (Franco Nero), sending the aging lothario into a jealous rage. Tristana is one of director Luis Bunuel’s more sombre efforts, but underlining this tragic tale of the corruption and abuse of power is his trade mark savage wit, his taste for sexual perversity (at one point a prosthetic leg is imbued with a strange erotic tension), and his contempt for the hypocrisy of the church and the ruling class. Adapted from a novel by Benito Perez Galdos. Cast includes Lola Gaos and Jesus Fernandez. In Spanish with English subtitles.

results.title: Tristan und Isolde
results.brief_description: A magnificent production by the Bayreuther Festspiele, under the direction of Daniel Barenboim and Jean-Pierre Ponnelle. Tristan, sung by Rene Kollo, and Isolde by Johanna Meier tells the tale of two fated lovers who are caught up in a web of intrigue. Ultimately the fulfillment of their love comes through death and transfiguration.

results.title: Tristan and Isolt = Lovespell
results.creator_credit: Clar Productions, Tom Hayes, Claire Labine and Tom Donovan
results.brief_description: A celtic medieval story of love, betrayal and tragedy within a 9th century Irish monarchy. Stars Richard Burton (Mark, King of Cornwall), Kate Mulgrew (Isolt), Nicholas Clay (Tristan) with Cyril Cusack, Geraldine Fitzgerald and Niall Toibin. Music by The Chieftains.

results.title: Triple word score [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Jane Keneally, AFTRS and Armagan Ballantyne
results.brief_description: Sisters Phyllis and Hazel prefer to communicate via the Scrabble board. When a stranger joins their midst, albeit briefly, they are forced to question their circumstances, and the nature of their relationship. Cast includes Iris Shand, Dorothy Cox and Ben Gabriel.

results.title: Triple trouble
results.creator_credit: Essanay Film Manufacturing Company, Charles Chaplin and Leo White
results.brief_description: A slapstick comedy starring Charlie Chaplin as a screwball kitchenhand who unwittingly foils Colonel W. Nutt’s scientific research and in the process involves everyone around him in a search for local train robbers. Also stars: Billy Armstrong, Albert Austin, Henry Bergman, Bud Jamison, James J. Kelley, ‘Snub’ Pollard, Edna Purviance, Wesley Ruggles and Leo White.

results.title: Tripe. Sharkey's party
results.creator_credit: Peter Lawless, Lawless Enterprises and Greg Woodland
results.brief_description: Tripe (1985): Gothic spoof in which four grown children read cookbooks for pleasure having been fed a steady diet of tripe by their domineering father and Victorian aunt Esme - until things get even blacker. Cast includes John Meillon, Gary Waddell, Sally McKenzie, Cate Brennan, Tim Ailwood and Steve Houston. “Sharkey’s Party” (1986): A less angst counterpoint to “Dogs in Space”. Having just come out of a mental institiution Sharkey’s friends throw him a party. Musicians, jaded punks, out-of-date hippies, sharehouses, drugs and life on the dole make up this portrayal of Australian youth culture in the 1980’s. Cast includes David Argue and Sally McKenzie.

results.title: Trio: exploring threads and textiles
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre and Ross Campbell
results.brief_description: A film for classroom teachers. Presents three different teachers in three different schools who have their own special way of incorporating Threads and Textiles into their program of Art Education. These teachers do not represent a random sample of teachers involved in using the course, but were simply selected because they were eager to introduce Threads and Textiles in to the classroom.
